Title: Spoofing the Browser External Entity
Description: Browser may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to Kerstel web server. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.

Title: Cross Site Scripting
Description: The web server 'Kerstel web server' could be a subject to a cross-site scripting attack because it does not sanitize untrusted input.

Title: Elevation Using Impersonation
Description: Kerstel web server may be able to impersonate the context of Browser in order to gain additional privilege.

Title: Elevation Using Impersonation
Description: Rest API may be able to impersonate the context of Kerstel web server in order to gain additional privilege.

Title: Rest API Process Memory Tampered
Description: If Rest API is given access to memory, such as shared memory or pointers, or is given the ability to control what Kerstel web server executes (for example, passing back a function pointer.), then Rest API can tamper with Kerstel web server. Consider if the function could work with less access to memory, such as passing data rather than pointers. Copy in data provided, and then validate it.

Title: Cross Site Scripting
Description: The web server 'Kerstel web server' could be a subject to a cross-site scripting attack because it does not sanitize untrusted input.

Title: Elevation Using Impersonation
Description: Kerstel web server may be able to impersonate the context of Rest API in order to gain additional privilege.

Title: Elevation Using Impersonation
Description: Rest API may be able to impersonate the context of SignalR in order to gain additional privilege.

Title: Spoofing the SignalR External Entity
Description: SignalR may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to Rest API. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.

Title: Elevation Using Impersonation
Description: Rest API may be able to impersonate the context of Mail API in order to gain additional privilege.

Title: Spoofing the Mail API External Entity
Description: Mail API may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to Rest API. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.

Title: Spoofing of Destination Data Store SQL Database
Description: SQL Database may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to data being written to the attacker's target instead of SQL Database. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the destination data store.

Title: Potential SQL Injection Vulnerability for SQL Database
Description: SQL injection is an attack in which malicious code is inserted into strings that are later passed to an instance of SQL Server for parsing and execution. Any procedure that constructs SQL statements should be reviewed for injection vulnerabilities because SQL Server will execute all syntactically valid queries that it receives. Even parameterized data can be manipulated by a skilled and determined attacker.

Title: Potential Excessive Resource Consumption for Rest API or SQL Database
Description: Does Rest API or SQL Database take explicit steps to control resource consumption? Resource consumption attacks can be hard to deal with, and there are times that it makes sense to let the OS do the job. Be careful that your resource requests don't deadlock, and that they do timeout.

Title: Spoofing of Source Data Store SQL Database
Description: SQL Database may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to incorrect data delivered to Rest API. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the source data store.

Title: Weak Access Control for a Resource
Description: Improper data protection of SQL Database can allow an attacker to read information not intended for disclosure. Review authorization settings.

Title: Spoofing of Source Data Store Secrets
Description: Secrets may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to incorrect data delivered to Rest API. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the source data store.

Title: Weak Access Control for a Resource
Description: Improper data protection of Secrets can allow an attacker to read information not intended for disclosure. Review authorization settings.

Title: Spoofing of Destination Data Store Secrets
Description: Secrets may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to data being written to the attacker's target instead of Secrets. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the destination data store.

Title: Potential Excessive Resource Consumption for Rest API or Secrets
Description: Does Rest API or Secrets take explicit steps to control resource consumption? Resource consumption attacks can be hard to deal with, and there are times that it makes sense to let the OS do the job. Be careful that your resource requests don't deadlock, and that they do timeout.

Title: Potential Process Crash or Stop for Kerstel web server
Description: Kerstel web server crashes, halts, stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.

Title: Potential Data Repudiation by Kerstel web server
Description: Kerstel web server claims that it did not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.

Title: Data Store Inaccessible
Description: An external agent prevents access to a data store on the other side of the trust boundary.

Title: Data Flow Responds Secrets Is Potentially Interrupted
Description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.

Title: Potential Process Crash or Stop for Kerstel web server
Description: Kerstel web server crashes, halts, stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.

Title: Weak Access Control for a Resource
Description: Improper data protection of Secrets can allow an attacker to read information not intended for disclosure. Review authorization settings.

Title: Data Flow HTTPS Request Is Potentially Interrupted
Description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.

Title: Kerstel web server May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote Code Execution
Description: Browser may be able to remotely execute code for Kerstel web server.

Title: Elevation by Changing the Execution Flow in Kerstel web server
Description: An attacker may pass data into Kerstel web server in order to change the flow of program execution within Kerstel web server to the attacker's choosing.

Title: Cross Site Request Forgery
Description: Cross-site request forgery (CSRF or XSRF) is a type of attack in which an attacker forces a user's browser to make a forged request to a vulnerable site by exploiting an existing trust relationship between the browser and the vulnerable web site.  In a simple scenario, a user is logged in to web site A using a cookie as a credential.  The other browses to web site B.  Web site B returns a page with a hidden form that posts to web site A.  Since the browser will carry the user's cookie to web site A, web site B now can take any action on web site A, for example, adding an admin to an account.  The attack can be used to exploit any requests that the browser automatically authenticates, e.g. by session cookie, integrated authentication, IP whitelisting. The attack can be carried out in many ways such as by luring the victim to a site under control of the attacker, getting the user to click a link in a phishing email, or hacking a reputable web site that the victim will visit. The issue can only be resolved on the server side by requiring that all authenticated state-changing requests include an additional piece of secret payload (canary or CSRF token) which is known only to the legitimate web site and the browser and which is protected in transit through SSL/TLS. See the Forgery Protection property on the flow stencil for a list of mitigations.

Title: Spoofing of the Browser External Destination Entity
Description: Browser may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to data being sent to the attacker's target instead of Browser. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.

Description: Browser claims that it did not receive data from a process on the other side of the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.

Description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
